article:
'Don Pomb Polye' [http://www.immigration.gov.pg/minister/65-ministers-key-note-
address-2011.html "Key Note Address to the 27th Papua New Guinea â Australia
Business Council Forum by the Hon. Don Pomb Polye, MP"], Papua New Guinean
Ministry for Immigration [http://www.bankpng.gov.pg/images/stories/sp-
peches/2011/Ministers_Speech_for_Launching_of_Strategic_Plan-Final.pdf "SPEECH
BY THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE & TREASURY, HONOURABLE DON POMB POLYE, AT THE LAUNCH
OF THE BANK OF PAPUA NEW GUINEA STRATEGIC PLAN 2012-15"], Bank of Papua New
Guinea is a senior Papua New Guinean politician from Enga Province and
currently the Minister for Treasuries of Papua New Guinea. He has been a Cabinet
Minister under two Prime Ministers to date, and was briefly deputy Prime
Minister from July to December 2010. Earlier, he has held Foreign Affairs,
Immigration, Transport, Civil Aviation, Finance and Treasury portfolios.

Polye was first elected in 2002 to the National Parliament of Papua New Guinea
representing the Kandep Open electorate as a member of the National Alliance
Party. He was the Minister for Transport and Civil Aviation from July 2006 to
August 2009. Sir Michael Somare, the Prime Minister, appointed Polye to that
position in July 2006 as part of a Cabinet reshuffle. [http://www.pm.gov.pg-
/pmsoffice/pmsoffice.nsf/pages/1785394D4A50905E4A2571A4000C7422?OpenDocument
Prime Minister of New Guinea media release "SIR MICHAEL MAKES MAJOR CABINET
RESHUFFLE" 5 July 2006] As Minister for Civil Aviation he introduced an
"open air" policy ensuring that Air Niugini faced competition from other
airlines starting from 2007.

Polye was rushed from a political rally in his Kandep electorate in June 2007
after shots were fired. A rival candidate for his seat was later charged with
attempted murder. [http://www.theage.com.au/news/World/Rival-denies-shooting-at-PNGs-
deputy-PM/2007/06/19/1182019086293.html The Age, "Rival denies shooting at PNG's
deputy PM" 19 June 2007]

Polye was removed from his position as Member of Parliament on 14 August 2009
when the National Court determined that his victory in the 2007 general election
was invalid. [http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20090817/news01.htm Post-
Courier, "Polye out" 17 August 2009] The judge's ruling included the
observation that it was hard to believe that some polling stations had returned
a 100% vote for Polye. [http://www.thenational.com.pg/?q=node/209 The
National, "Red-faced", 28 August 2009] The by-election for the seat took
place on 9 November 2009, and Polye ran as a
candidate. [http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20090827/news01.htm Post-Courier,
"Hâlands âhopeâ back to polls" 27 August 2009] He was successful in
regaining his seat.

In July 2010, he replaced Puka Temu as deputy Prime Minister, when the latter
tried unsuccessfully to unseat Prime Minister Somare through a parliamentary
motion of no confidence. [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/somare-jets-off-
after-cementing-rule/story-e6frg6so-1225895813589 "Somare jets off after
cementing rule"], [[The Australian]], 23 July 2010 Polye himself was
removed as deputy Prime Minister on 7 December 2010, in an impromptu cabinet
reshuffle conducted under what Australia's ABC News called "unusual
circumstances". Fox, Liam:
[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/12/08/3087673.htm Deputy PM sacked in
PNG shake-up], ABC News, 8 December 2010. However he was appointed as
Papua New Guinea's Foreign Minister later in December 2010, holding that
position until another cabinet reshuffle in June 2011. He supported the
Opposition when it brought down the government through a parliamentary motion of
no confidence in August 2011, and was appointed Minister for Finance by new
Prime Minister Peter O'Neill. [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/world-leaders-1/world-
leaders-p/papua-new-guinea.html Cabinet of Papua New Guinea], CIA Factbook, 18
August 2011

In October, the National Alliance Party consequently sought to expel him from
the party, but was prevented from doing so by a court
order. [http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20111006/news03.htm "Court stops NA
from sacking Don Polye"], Post Courier, 6 October 2011 Later that month,
it was reported simultaneously that Polye, along with many others, had been
expelled from the party "for conduct prejudicial to the interest of the party",
and that he had been elected as party leader. [http://www.pina.com.fj/?p=pa-
cnews&m=read&o=20504882634e97b66e5f5e8eed3b3c "National Alliance party sack 12
parliamentarians, leader calls on party executives to resign"], Pacific Islands
News Association In fact, the party split into factions, one of which was
led by Polye. In January 2012, he announced that he was de-registering the
National Alliance Party, despite the existence of a rival faction claiming to be
the legitimate party. Polye and his faction launched a new party, the Triumph
Heritage Empowerment Rural Party ("T.H.E. Party"), ahead of the June 2012
general election. [http://www.islandsbusiness.com/news/index_dynamic/contai-
nerNameToReplace=MiddleMiddle/focusModuleID=130/focusContentID=26867/tableName=-
mediaRelease/overideSkinName=newsArticle-full.tpl "Polye splits National
Alliance party, forms new group to contest 2012 polls"], [[Islands Business]],
17 January 2012 [http://pidp.eastwestcenter.org/pireport/2012/January/01-24-
04.htm "PNGâS DEFUNCT RULING PARTY REFORMS AS âT.H.E. PARTYâ"], The National, 23
January 2012 [http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20120124/tuhome.htm "New
party launched"], Post Courier, 24 January
2012 [http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=65706 "New PNG
political party to focus on strengthening family unit"], Radio New Zealand
International, 24 January 2012

On 27 February 2012, Prime Minister Peter O'Neill relieved him of the Finance
portfolio, taking it on himself, citing "the continuing lack of ability by the
department and ministry of finance to contain expenditure overruns outside of
the budget appropriations". Polye retained the Treasury portfolio, and gained
that of Border Development. [http://www.thenational.com.pg/?q=node/29601
"Polye loses powers"], The National, 28 February 2012 Following the
results of the 2012 general election Polye retained his position as Treasurer
under a new cabinet announced by O'Neill. [http://www.radioaustralia.net.au-
/international/radio/program/pacific-beat/png-pm-announces-full-cabinet-
membership/997290 "PNG PM announces full cabinet membership"], ABC Radio
Australia, 11 August 2012
